utterances: That was cilantro-hating producer Josh Kurz.
If you'd like to find out whether or not you are a supertaster, go to our Web site.
It's npr.org.
(Soundbite of music)
More to come on Day to Day.
Former special counsel Robert Mueller testified before Congress yesterday, and he said that Russian interference in U.S.
elections is still a real threat.
Listen to this exchange between Mueller and Will Hurd, a Republican congressman from Texas.
(SOUNDBITE OF ARCHIVED RECORDING)
In your investigation, did you think that this was a single attempt by the Russians to get involved in our election, or did you find evidence to suggest they'll try to do this again?
Oh, it wasn't a single attempt.
They're doing it as we sit here, and they expect to do it during the next campaign.
NPR's Tim Mak watched the hearings.
He's been following all of this.
Hey, Tim.
Hey, there.
So what else did Mueller say about foreign interference in our elections?
Yeah, Mueller was really clear about how pressing of an issue this is and has been for U.S.
intelligence and law enforcement agencies.
As we heard a little bit earlier, he said that the Russians engaged in disinformation and are engaging in disinformation right now as we sit here.
But he also said that other foreign actors, other foreign countries are starting their own operations and getting involved in this space, as well.
Disinformation is a low-cost, high-reward method for some of these malicious actors, and they can spread a lot of mayhem in the American democratic process.
And Mueller says he fully expects that the Russian government will take part in election interference again in 2020.
Tim, did he say what any of the other countries were that might interfere in our elections?
He didn't get into that.
That would kind of get into intelligence material and classified information, so he didn't specifically mention any countries.
But we have a general good sense about some of the actors who have started to get into this space, such as Iran or North Korea.
OK, and did Mueller then offer any suggestions to Congress about what it should do about this?
Yeah, Mueller sees himself as a prosecutor and not a legislator, so he was kind of tight-lipped even on the things that related to his role as a prosecutor.
He didn't have any new proposals or suggestions for lawmakers.
He's leaving that to Congress.
OK, so what do members of Congress say?
So there is support there that is compatible with their spirituality and their religious beliefs, but yet there is that ability to comprehend and understand their social and emotional needs as well.
John Tartibuno, the psychologist who met with local Amish people the night of the shootings, was surprised to find them talking about more than simply supporting the families of the victims.
They were talking about helping the family of the killer, a man who lived nearby but who wasn't Amish.
They were talking about how they can support and help his family.
They're planning to send a contingent over and perhaps bringing them some food, and they've already gotten to the point of forgiveness.
Still, for the Amish, just like any community, there will be hard work to deal with the tragic shooting that shattered the peace of their community.
Joseph Shapiro, NPR News.
From NPR News, this is ALL THINGS CONSIDERED.
I'm Michele Norris.
And I'm Melissa Block.
For one week every August on the outskirts of the Black Hills National Forest in South Dakota, the little town of Sturgis is famous for making more than its fair share of racket.
The Sturgis Motorcycle Rally, a sort of weeklong biker camping party, starts again next Monday.
It attracts roughly half a million bikers, and already the complaints are coming in from the neighbors.
The Lakota Indian Tribe is protesting the new construction of a gigantic biker bar and not far away, a huge amphitheatre for rock concerts.
They say it's disturbing the peace near Bear Butte, a mountain the plains Indians consider sacred.
Gary Lippold owns Glencoe Camp Resort near Sturgis, and that's where the amphitheatre is.
Hi, Mr. Lippold.
Hi.
How are you, Melissa?
I'm okay.
Can you tell us about your concert venue?
How big is it?
Well, it covers 34 acres.
It's on some property that's been in my family for over 100 years.
We started the campground 24 years ago, and it's just kind of a natural progression.
We've decided that we needed a first-class music facility here at the rally, and this is what we started building.
And how many people will you be able to seat at those concerts?
Probably in the 40,000-50,000 neighborhood for sure.
And who do you have playing?
Oh, we have five nights this year.
We have Big and Rich and we have Keith Urban.
We got the Steve Miller Band.
We have Nickelback, Tom Petty and the Heartbreakers, Joe Cocker, Sammy Hagar, REO Speedwagon, 38 Special, Georgia Satellites, to just give you a few.
Now you're about three miles from the mountain that's in question here.
Have you been hearing from the Lakota members who are upset about how big this has gotten and how close it is to Bear Butte?
Well, I actually invited them out when we started the construction.
And we went through the facility and I showed them all the work I was going to do to diminish the impact this would have on all my neighbors.
I have two good friends that live over that direction.
And we moved over 1.2 million cubic yards of dirt, so all the sound will be absorbed into the amphitheatre.
The only possible sound that would escape would be the deep bass sound, because it comes out circular sound waves instead of straight sound waves.
And we checked with the sound people, and they said that we will have between 75 and 85 decibels at the edge of our amphitheatre.
And, of course, three miles away, they felt that if you heard anything, you would hear just sound like thunder in the background.
Just light thunder.
A motorcycle driving by is about 95 decibels, so we would be much less than even the highway that runs right by the state park.
Do you understand the concerns that they're raising?
They're saying that they have men up on the mountain fasting and praying and they're listening to all this construction noise.
And that hard as you may try to contain it, it's going to seep out and it's going to disturb what they consider to be a very sacred place.
Well, they haven't heard any of the construction noise from our facility.
I think there's a lot of crying wolf here.
There's several facilities much, much closer.
I understand their concerns, but, you know, there is a buffer zone around Bear Butte - it's called a state park.
And just to claim nobody can develop their property within that five-mile area is unrealistic.
Well, I guess the Lakota have a protest camp that they're setting up and they're talking about possibly stopping traffic on the road that would lead up to your place.
It doesn't sound like there's a meeting of minds here.
Well, I hope they don't do that.
Because I don't think it's going to serve any purpose.
You know, I tried from the very beginning to explain to them, and explain to everybody, that growth is inevitable.
I mean you can resist it or you can meet on it and work out the solutions that work for the best of all parties.
And they have taken a hard line that there's just not going to be any growth out this direction.
And that's too bad, because if we want to provide jobs for our young people here in Sturgis, we have to continue to develop and do become more commercialized.
Most of our youth have to leave the state because there's no job opportunities here for them.
Well, Mr. Lippold, thanks for talking with us.
Appreciate it.
You bet, Melissa.
Gary Lippold owns the Glencoe Camp Resort near Sturgis, South Dakota, where Bike Week starts on Monday.

and conspiracy to help a terrorist group.
When prosecutors bring terrorism cases to court, conspiracy is one of the most common charges.
NPR's Ari Shapiro reports on why prosecutors love it and why it makes some civil libertarians uncomfortable.
